channel.title: metrics on ebullient·works
channel.description: Recent content in metrics on ebullient·works

item.title: QCon Plus: The mechanics of metrics
item.description:
Speaking at the QCon Plus virtual conference was a nice experience. Each track had an ad-hoc meeting room that you could join after the session, which was really cool. It was nice to be able to speak with people that watched my talk directly. It brought back a bit of the in-person conference feel.

Of course the first question was “Which edition of D&D?” (5e), what I didn’t expect was the next question, “Is that the new Sesame Street Lego set?” (yes).

The recording will be generally available in August of 2022!

item.title: Know your app: Add metrics to Java with Micrometer
airhacks.fm: MicroProfile Metrics, Micrometer and Quarkus — podcast with Adam Bien
item.description: I thoroughly enjoy talking with Adam. We sat down awhile ago to talk about metrics: who needs them, what they are for.. and some other things.

item.title: DevNexus 2021: The Mechanics of Metrics
item.description:
A reframing of the metrics talk, with a much more detailed look at how emitted metrics are aggregated by PromQL / Grafana dashboards.

I quite like this one, to be honest.

item.title: J4K 2020: Metrics for the win!
item.description: A longer form of Metrics for the Win! recorded for J4K, which occurred in October of 2020.

item.title: JConf 2020: Metrics for the win!
item.description: A fully online recorded talk, sliding in at just 30 minutes, for JConf in the fall of 2020.

item.title: DevNexus 2020: Metrics for the Win
item.description: While not recorded, it was nice to revisit and brush up the Monster Combat application. I enjoyed working with Quarkus! Micrometer was easy to bring in as a third-partly library.

item.title: SpringOne 2019: Monsters and Metrics
item.description:
Two things collided in my brain this year ahead of SpringOne: Preparing a new talk from scratch covering the Micrometer (and the related Spring implementation), and learning everything I needed to know to be a Dungeon Master for my 10-year-old son and his friends.

Thanks to a brilliant suggestion from a friend, these two things collided in the talk, too. Which lightened the mental load (or at least reduced the amount of full stack swapping going on).

Github repository: ebullient/monster-combat with Spring Boot 2, WebFlux, and Micrometer

And hooray! ;)

My day has just been made. Someone that attended my @s1p talk just stopped me as we got off the plane to let me know they liked it. 😇☺️ I hope everyone else enjoyed Austin this week!

— Erin Schnabel (@ebullient@mastodon.social) (@ebullientworks) October 11, 2019

item.title: SpringOne 2019 Preview: Metrics for the Win
item.description: Mark is one of my favorite humans. It is always lovely to talk with him. Mark Heckler talks with Erin Schnabel about her SpringOnePlatform talk: Metrics for the Win: Using Micrometer to Understand Application Behavior. Schnabel, E. (2019, September 5). Using Micrometer to Understand Application Behavior, a SpringOne Platform preview (M. Heckler, Interviewer) [Interview]. In Tanzu Talk (formerly Pivotal Conversations). https://soundcloud.com/pivotalconversations/using-micrometer-to-understand-application-behavior
